descript.abstract:
In 2009, the Kentucky Water Science Center completed the Water Availability Tool for Environmental Resources (WATER-KY), which provided the ability to simulate streamflow for the period 1980-2000. This model integrated TOPMODEL (Beven and Kirkby, 1979) for pervious portions of the landscape with simulation of flow generated from impervious surfaces (USDA, 1986). Associated products included a flow-duration curve, load-duration curves when water-quality data were available, and general water balance. WATER-KY required a dedicated ArcGIS license with the Spatial Analyst extension, which made it difficult to use for some cooperators and limited integration with other hydrologic approaches. This new version translates the abilities of WATER to a format that can be used without proprietary software or local updating of software. Additional functionality has also been added to include hydrologic response units (HRUs) that are defined based on three fundamental land-use categories: forest, agricultural land, and developed areas, based on subsequent development of WATER for the Delaware Basin (Williamson and others, 2015). Beven, K.J., and Kirkby, M.J., 1979, A physically based, variable contributing area model of basin hydrology / Un modèle à base physique de zone d'appel variable de l'hydrologie du bassin versant: Hydrological Sciences Bulletin v. 24, p. 43-69, http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/02626667909491834.
U.S. Department of Agriculture [USDA], 1986, Urban hydrology for small watersheds: Natural Resources Conservation Service, Conservation Engineering Division, Technical Release 55, Revised June 1986, Update of Appendix A January 1999, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb1044171.pdf.
Williamson, T.N., Lant, J.G., Claggett, P.R., Nystrom, E.A., Milly, P.C.D., Nelson, H.L., Hoffman, S.A., Colarullo, S.J., and Fischer, J.M., 2015, Summary of hydrologic modeling for the Delaware River Basin using the Water Availability Tool for Environmental Resources (WATER): U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report 2015–5143, 68 p., http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/sir20155143. Multiple spatial data sets (topographic, soils, climate) for the basin of interest are sampled from the provided database using the geospatial.py process provided with WATER and a basin shapefile provided by the user. Alternatively, representative data can be provided by the user. Basin-specific data are provided to the tool as the "basin_characteristics.csv" and the "twi.csv". Additionally, the user must select a hydrologic response unit parameterization (parameters_forested, parameters_agricultural, or parameters_developed) based on the most abundant land use in the basin. No domain ranges are provided for the basin_characteristics because these are site specific. This simplified metadata is being provided as a template of what is used to inform simulations. Source data and metadata are provided with the database. Output from the tool is in a time series that covers the duration of time included in the precipitation and temperature record, less one year that is used to initialize the model. Numerical values will vary as a function of the area of interest and the time period that is simulated, so no ranges are included. This simplified metadata is being provided as an explanation of what variables are provided by the simulation.

idinfo.useconst: Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Dataset is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the associated metadata records carefully for additional details

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

eainfo.detailed:
basin_characteristics.csv Comma Separated Value (CSV) file. This is described as the individual rows required in the file. must follow example format
headers Required column heading for file
name Parameter name
value Numerical value of parameter
units Units for parameter
description General description of parameter
scaling_parameter Integrates soil thickness, porosity, and hydraulic conductivity to integrate basin topography and soil characteristics Available From Database millimeters
saturated_hydraulic_conductivity Saturated hydraulic conductivity of soil profile Available From Database millimeters per day
saturated_hydraulic_conductivity_multiplier Controls the rate of decline of conductivity in the soil profile Available From Database unitless
soil_depth_total Thickness of hydrologically-active soil Available From Database millimeters
field_capacity_fraction proportion of soil profile that retains water at field capacity; characterizes soil-water retained after gravity drainage Available From Database fraction
porosity_fraction proportion of soil profile that is pore space Available From Database fraction
wilting_point_fraction proportion of soil profile that retains water at wilting point; this water is not available to plants and this porosity does not provide for storm response Available From Database fraction
latitude mean latitude of basin Determined during geospatial sampling; used to calculate potential evapotranspiration degrees
basin_area_total total basin area Determined during geospatial sampling; used to convert water budget (in millimeters) to a streamflow volume square kilometers
impervious_area_fraction Impervious area of basin; used to calculate runoff from impervious surface Available From Database percentage
channel_length_max Estimate used to initialize simulation Producer Defined kilometers
channel_velocity_avg Estimate used to initialize simulation Producer Defined kilometers per day
flow_initial Estimate used to initialize simulation Producer Defined millimeters per day
lake_area Total waterbody surface area Determined during geospatial sampling square kilometers
up_lake_area Basin area upstream of water bodies Determined during geospatial sampling square kilometers
rip_area Area of stream corridor Determined during geospatial sampling square kilometers
#tnw - items below here need to move to parameters
lake_delay Estimated time for water to move through lake measured in days: 15, 1.5, 1.5 Available From Database days
eff_imp Used to decrease the percent impervious in landscapes that are forested: 0.7, 1, 1 Available From Database percentage
imp_delay Proportion of precipitation delayed to next day from impervious surface and associated runoff; 0.1, 0.5, 0.1 Available From Database decimal
twi_adj Used to decrease importance of topography in developed landscapes; 1,1,0.5 Available From Database unitless
et_exp_dorm minimizes evapotranspiration during dormant season; 5 Available From Database unitless
et_exp_grow maximizes evapotranspiration during dormant season; 0.5 Available From Database unitless
#tnw removed above

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing a 30-bin distribution of the tophographic wetness index of the basin. This proportional distribution should be in the decimal form and the cell distribution is in percent.

attr.attrdef: sum of the column within 1% of 1.0

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.
enttyp.enttypds: Producer defined and specific to majority land cover (Forested, Agricultural, Developed). This is described as the individual rows required in the parameter file.

attr.attrdef: used to optimize the scaling parameter
proportion of soil thickness used for evapotranspiration
fraction of precipitation that can bypass the unsaturated subsurface zone and move directly into the saturated subsurface zone
TR55 parameter
temperature cutoff for snowpack accumulation and snowmelt
used to control rate of snow melt
attr.attrunit: millimeters per degrees Celsius per day

attr.attrdef: Controls rate of snow melt when raining
attr.attrunit: millimeters per degrees Celsius per day

attr.attrdef: Adjusts potential evapotranspiration for regional conditions
Estimated time for water to move through lake
Used to decrease the percent impervious in landscapes that are forested
Proportion of precipitation delayed to next day from impervious surface and associated runoff
Used to decrease importance of topography in developed landscapes
minimizes evapotranspiration during dormant season
maximizes evapotranspiration during dormant season

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing simulation results from tool.

attr.attrdef: Date pulled from the timeseries file provided during input.
attr.attrunit: Date in the format of mm/dd/yyyy.

attr.attrdef: Pulled from timeseries.
Pulled from timeseries.
Optionally included with climate file for statistical evaluation.
potential evapotranspiration
attr.attrdefs: Either pulled from climate file input (if provided by user) or calculated within the simulation

attr.attrdef: Actual evapotranspiration
Precipitation minus Potential Evapotranspiration (PET); determines if there is precipitation for recharge.
Amount of new water infiltrated into soil
Quantity of infiltration-excess overland flow
Quantity of water bypassing root zone as a function of sinkhole distribution
Flow from the impervious surface
Average soil-water storage in root zone
Daily sum of simulated streamflow
Daily maximum of hourly-simulated streamflow
Daily minimum of hourly-simulated streamflow
Daily median of hourly-simulated streamflow
Daily mean of hourly-simulated streamflow
Daily maximum of hourly-simulated streamflow
attr.attrdefs: Converted from mm per hour using basin area

attr.attrdef: Daily minimum of hourly-simulated streamflow
attr.attrdefs: Converted from mm per hour using basin area

attr.attrdef: Daily median of hourly-simulated streamflow
attr.attrdefs: Converted from mm per hour using basin area

attr.attrdef: Daily mean of hourly-simulated streamflow
attr.attrdefs: Converted from mm per hour using basin area

attr.attrdef: Open pore space available to store water in the total soil thickness averaged for all TWI bins. A value of 0 means that all pore space is filled.
Overland flow from exfiltration after soil is saturated
Quantity of water that re-infiltrates into the soil

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing simulation results from tool.
enttyp.attrdef: Bin-specific values of open pore space available to store water in the total soil thickness. A value of 0 means that all pore space is filled.

attr.attrdef: Date pulled from the timeseries file provided during input.

attrdomv.udom: Date in the format of mm/dd/yyyy

attr.attrdef: Lower bin numbers indicate drier landscape positions. 30 bins total.

distinfo.distliab: Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. Although this information product, for the most part, is in the public domain, it may contain copyrighted materials. Permission to reproduce copyrighted items must be secured from the copyright owner. The data have been approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Although the data have been subjected to rigorous review and are substantially complete, the USGS reserves the right to revise the data pursuant to further analysis and review. Furthermore, the data are released on the condition that neither the USGS nor the U.S. Government may be held liable for any damages resulting from authorized or unauthorized use. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The USGS or the U.S. Government shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. Users of these data are advised to read all metadata and associated documentation thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
distinfo.techpreq: This zip file contains data in Climate and Forecast-Network Common Data Form (CF-netCDF) that were developed for use with the WATERpy hydrologic model. When the database is downloaded please note the file structure of the climate data must not change for the tool to run. The user must have the ability to utilize these file formats if they are to be used independently.

metainfo.metstdn: Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
